comments.commentBody: Those Californians who are so keen on harsh prison sentences and the like need to put their money where their mouth is. They need to agree to have their taxes raised to pay for the increased prison population. Or they need to agree to reduce the budgets for education or health services or whatever. After all, there ain't no free lunch and the increase in costs for prisons needs to come from somewhere.

Here's a novel idea for keeping our prisons from overcrowding: don't make possession/ingestion of marijuana a parole violation. Start putting people behind bars for crimes that actually hurt someone.

Or even better yet, kill a few birds (ie: the budget, problems with mexican drug cartels, the incredible ease with which minors can get pot) by legalizing marijuana, taxing the multi-billion dollar business, and regulating who grows and buys it.

What percentage of those prisoners released early from jail will be arrested in the next year? This is something to consider: It seems like the state is saving money in the short term, only to be flushing more money down the drain again with impending recidivism.
I wonder if it's more expensive for a society to keep  criminals in jail or, instead,  having 6,500 of them among honest people.

I'm writing a story about a man who wakes up one morning and doesn't recognize himself in the mirror. But unlike Kafka's story “Metamorphosis,” my character's appearance didn't actually change, but the image in the mirror is a stranger to him. Has there ever been a case like that? Could such a thing be considered a form of amnesia, or BDD?
Why stop here?  They can also push for repeal of Medicare and Social Security.  A real Republican Trifecta!
A remark that was spontaneous with unfiltered truth, that may imply, they had no idea how big a deal they got...and now have no idea how to implement it.

A lot folks posting here believe the nobility of their cause, gives them the right to confiscate the fruits of someone else's labor.

White slave owners forced slaves to contribute to all sorts of charitable causes of the owner's choosing. Did the nobility of those causes justify slavery? No, it did not.

A swear of joy and honesty vs. a curse of hate and vileness. I'll take the VPs oath and raise him one! Used the way Joe Biden did, it's ebullient. Used the way Cheny did, it's loathsome.

The republicans have no moral high ground to stand on here. (In fact, they have no moral high ground at all any more.)
Tell Senator Isakson his insurance has just been cancelled . . . you know how it is . .
Robert Woodburn -- Doesn't capitalism require the recycling of 'other people's money' too?

jacobi -- Actually you predict what will happen as though you have a crystal ball.

You said 'America will pay the price.' Wow. What a bold prophecy.

And you've got a lot of nerve calling the commentary of others 'bloviating.'

Lessee - if you watch four hours of television, how many times do you hear this? So once more won't kill anybody.

@Nacho Homey

Did you see where our WONDERFUL attorney general is one of the jerks bringing suit over this bill? How do we rid ourselves of these fleas?

Earth to Mitch, your side lost....your side lied...your team feed fear and mis-lead the public....your side does not have Healthcare plan for America...now, just get over and have a mint julep and sing My Old Kentucky Home.

It's surprising to see how many Americans continue to sling mud at someone with a different opinion, especially since each of us wants our opinion respected.  I see the facts as that health care reform is needed, just how best to do that is what is being bitterly debated, and personally I think that's good.  The one thing that concerns me the most is that a 2700 page document was written, with very few individuals invovled in that process, and certainly not open to the Amreican people who will be completely affected by it, with only 72 hours to review not only the 2700 pages but also the additional reconcilliation. Hhmmmmmm....possible? No.  Did our congress vote on something they personally had time to review and understand? No.  Were there deals made and pressure placed to get a YES vote...of course.  Should we the people know what those deals were and who they are going to affect?  I think so.  Before the name calling begins and the insults are thrown...read the bill yorself and figure out what you want to say. This bill is going to have a very profound affect on you, your family, our children and the soundness of strenght of America. Please do something usefull...know what you're talking about first and save the energy used for insults and name calling to educate yourself...democrat or republican!  At the end of the day...the "other side" jsut might have a point!  Personally, I'm for American freedom and having laws in place that encourage each individual to seek out the best in themselves, to have respect and pride in themselves, and to be able to follow the "American dream" that has made America great!  Educate yourself America...something really important is happening here!!!

Yikes! I just heard Alaska's Murkowsky quote her mammy "She used to tell me If it sounds too good to be true, it most likely...." - how deep!

This is getting sublime, I don't think even the most sophomoric of the gals in our secretarial pool would have the idiocy of uttering that phrase in mixed company, yet there it is on the Senate floor.

The Republicans seem bent on redefining the word "loser" in a way that will make Wiley E. Coyote an Olympian champion.

Hey GOP... you just keep this self flagellation up and soon the ark will be nearly empty, the Independents are bailing out by the boatloads and the Conservatives are not far behind them they would rather drown than be associated with this circus side show. Soon only the halfwits of the Teabaggies will be left on board waving posters of Sarah and the blond blue eyed Jesus along with the Skinheads waving the Aryan flag. Oh, them and the political clair voyant from Laguna Niguel.

Have fun in Never Never land fellas.

Carly of the failed business policies is now joined by Condi of the failed national policies - only on the biggest loser would this make a winning team.

Yes siree folks... and the GOP is lining them up for you to take a shot at - three tries with this here basket ball and any dummy knocked down will get you a kewpie doll for your doll.

This is getting sublime.

This is only helping the insurance companies who clearly operate as a subsidiary of the banking system and who already have massive influence over our government. They're not loosing a dime gaining 32 million people. Just look at how the stocks skyrocketed today. Do you have any idea how much this is going to cost hard working folks? Proponents of this bill are only thinking one thought - free health - but they're not taking into consideration the serious social, economic and political ramifications of such bold and radicalized legislation.

Personally, this slaps the face of decency and democracy. Unfortunately, many think that decency lies in giving to and supporting those who would do little to help themselves, I submit that decency rests in teaching people how to care for themselves and earn their keep. Our founding fathers continuously warned us of this path towards government dependency and of abandoning the idea of personal responsibility.

I just want to add that I'm for lowering health care costs as I am for lowering the cost of many things that have been artificially inflated through the licentious practices of the Federal Reserve and the profligacy of fractional reserve banking. Most of my anger stems from this fictitious black and white argument of the government vs. insurance companies, which is simply a complete fabrication to anyone exercising common sense. The argument is rigged. No matter what side you take, the ruling establishment is controlled by the same companies and banking overlords that they pretend to be fighting against. To think that such enormous wealth and influence don't have absolute control of the process speaks volumes to the idiocy and domestication of modern man.

The theft of the American people continues as our country slips into the abyss, on the horizon, a larger agenda begins to manifest.
Representative "Foot-in-mouth" should make amends by organizing a movement to have Texas secede from the Union offer the state for sale to the Mexican government (if they would have them)

It's amazing how self destructive liberalism is. The country gave them a little bit of rope. Instead of behaving themselves they tied it around their neck and jumped off the chair on Sunday. They are going to get such a spanking in November and I'm sure they won't understand why. They just don't understand America.

as usual, wonderfully observed and well written thoughts; some of the critics, I think, may not appreciate how much longer and how much more of a consistent grind the MLB season is than the NFL or NHL or NBA, as overly long and bloated (compared to my youth in the late 60s/early 70s) as they've all become.

Despite the seemingly relaxed nature & pace of the game, IMO only those who have played it at a relatively high level (higher than my own college experience) can understand the depth & verity of Doug's observations. What we struggled to maintain over 25-40 games, MLB players do for 180+ including spring training. It's an athletic stratosphere to be sure, but the grind is no less daunting because of the nature of the game (IMO) than the shorter football, basketball, or hockey seasons.

As you suggest, the most credible way to be pro-Israel is to be pro-peace. Quite neatly, as Gen. Petraeus (or his statement!) pointed out, being pro-Israel is also being pro-America. (Funny, Gary Bauer & other evangelicals from the "real" America are not pro-America.) It's really much simpler than the saber-rattling land-grabbers would have us think. Here's hoping a few journalists catch your drift, too.

Unfortunately for Mr. Netanyahu, who has chosen to move further to the right to shore up his right wing, he will likely end up the paschal lamb, an unintended self-sacrifice, to be sure. His defiant speech before AIPAC, combined with the concurrent settlement news, made for an international disgrace. (Having his ambassador tossed out of Britain today didn't help his stature, either.) But you can see why he gets on so well with John McCain, who yesterday stamped his feet on the Senate floor & and announced, "There will be no cooperation for the rest of the year." These are not men who have the best interests of their nations or of humankind at heart. Neither is a patriot. This nation rejected John McCain. We who are pro-Israel and pro-U.S. hope Israel rejects Bibi Netanyahu soon. Peace for both our nations and the Palestinians hangs in the balance.

The Constant Weader at www.RealityChex.com

>>East Jerusalem lies beyond Israel’s internationally recognized, pre-1967 borders.<<

Your premise is faulty. There was an armistice line in 1949 where the armies stopped, and the Arabs specifically said that this was not a border.

A bit more on the subject of the Armistice Line (which became the Green Line). From the agreement with Jordan:

""... no provision of this Agreement shall in any way prejudice the rights, claims, and positions of either Party hereto in the peaceful settlement of the Palestine questions, the provisions of this Agreement being dictated exclusively by military considerations"

and

"The Armistice Demarcation Lines defined in articles V and VI of this Agreement are agreed upon by the Parties without prejudice to future territorial settlements or boundary lines or to claims of either Party relating thereto."

So if the parties to the Armitice agree it wasn't a border -- and perhaps this was the only thing they ever agreed on -- then it certainly isn't a winning argument to claims that this was an internationally recognized border.

I don't see why Hillary Clinton has to kowtow to AIPAC. It's a lobbying organization, and the government can legitimately disagree with AIPAC's positions and still be supportive of Israel's right to exist as an independent Jewish and democratic state.

Additionally, I have long thought that Abe Foxman's hyperbolic, hyperactive defense of Jewish interests -- he defines them -- is counterproductive. And you may had Alan Dershowitz and Marvin Hier to that list of counterproductive self-appointed defenders of the Jews. And for full disclosure, I am a former resident of Jerusalem (West Jerusalem) who has moved to the U.S.
